  • • Talus, S2, and S3:

questions.text: A child before playing consumed fruit from the garden. After some time, he developed a high fever, confusion, photophobia, and unable to urinate. What are the likely causative agent and the appropriate antidote used in this case? ( NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Datura, Physostigmine

questions.text: Black foot is seen in which poisoning: ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Arsenic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Arsenic, cadmium, lead and mercury are the heavy metals which can cause peripheral vascular disease due to chronic poisoning. This leads to general clinical features of peripheral vascular disease (numbness in feet, rest pain etc.). Blackfoot disease is a unique term given to peripheral vascular disease produced by chronic Arsenic poisoning. The name "Blackfoot" refers to the characteristic darkening and gangrene of the feet and lower legs. This ultimately leads to amputation. In peripheral vascular disease caused by other heavy metals, gangrene is not a common manifestation
  • ➤ Arsenic, cadmium, lead and mercury are the heavy metals which can cause peripheral vascular disease due to chronic poisoning. This leads to general clinical features of peripheral vascular disease (numbness in feet, rest pain etc.).
  • ➤ Blackfoot disease is a unique term given to peripheral vascular disease produced by chronic Arsenic poisoning. The name "Blackfoot" refers to the characteristic darkening and gangrene of the feet and lower legs. This ultimately leads to amputation.
  • ➤ In peripheral vascular disease caused by other heavy metals, gangrene is not a common manifestation
  • ➤ Above picture shows Blackfoot disease:

questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Liver and lungs
  • ➤ Brain
  • ➤ Heart
  • ➤ Kidney

  • ➤ Skin, muscle, tendons
  • ➤ Bones and teeth

  • ➤ Mnemonic: LBHK
  • ➤ Mnemonic:
  • ➤ L for larynx, liver, lungs, B for brain H for Heart, K for Kidney

questions.text: 2 handkerchiefs with blood stains are found at a crime scene. What is the most appropriate procedure for handling these items? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Place them in same plastic bag and seat it for preservation

options.label: B
options.text: Preserve in envelope or paper bag

options.label: C
options.text: Fold the handkerchiefs in such a manner that the stained edges come together

options.label: D
options.text: Place them in different plastic bags and seal for preservation

questions.correct_answer: B. Preserve in envelope or paper bag
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Preserve in envelope or paper bag

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When handling blood-stained items found at a crime scene, preserve them in an envelope or paper bag to allow for air circulation, and dry the stains in the shade or by air drying to prevent DNA denaturation. Avoid using plastic bags or exposing the stains to direct sunlight or heat.
  • ➤ Avoid using plastic bags or exposing the stains to direct sunlight or heat.

questions.text: During a police investigation, bones are uncovered at the crime scene. What key characteristic feature would be crucial in differentiating between human and animal bones, aiding forensic analysis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Precipitin test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The precipitin test is the key characteristic feature used to differentiate between human and animal bones found at a crime scene. This test is species-specific and can be applied to various tissues, including blood, semen, and bones. The formation of a precipitate upon the addition of an anti-human serum to the sample extract indicates the presence of human tissue.

questions.text: What is the antidote of cyanide poisoning? (INICET MAY 2024) A. Amyl Nitrite B. Sodium Nitrite C. Sodium Thiosulphate D. Benzyl Thiocyanate E. Sodium Nitroprusside
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) ABC

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The main antidotes for cyanide poisoning include amyl nitrite, sodium nitrite, and sodium thiosulphate. These agents work by either converting cyanide into a less toxic form or by forming methemoglobin which binds to cyanide, freeing cytochrome C oxidase .

questions.text: Arrange symptoms as in their order of appearance as seen in iron toxicity:(INICET MAY 2021) Pyloric stricture Asymptomatic phase Gastrointestinal bleeding Liver failure and hypoglycemia
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 3 → 2 → 4 → 1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iron toxicity progresses through distinct stages, starting with gastrointestinal irritation and bleeding, followed by an asymptomatic phase, then liver failure and hypoglycemia, and finally, bowel obstruction leading to pyloric stricture.

questions.text: What is a characteristic feature of a contact gunshot wound? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Stellate wound

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • A stellate wound is a hallmark of contact gunshot wounds, particularly when the gun is fired against a firm surface like the skull. The gases and pressure from the gunshot cause the skin to burst and tear radially, creating a star-shaped, or stellate, pattern. This type of wound is caused by the high-pressure gases and thermal effects of the discharge directly impacting and penetrating the skin at the point of contact.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Abraded collar: Incorrect for this context, as an abraded collar is typical of close, but not necessarily contact, shots where the bullet scrapes the skin upon entry.
  • • Option B. Abraded collar:
  • • Option C. Grease collar: Incorrect, this refers to a deposit from the bullet or barrel, not typically prominent in contact shots due to the nature of the discharge.
  • • Option C. Grease collar:
  • • Option D. Tattooing: Incorrect for contact shots, as tattooing from unburned powder particles occurs at close range but outside of direct contact.
  • • Option D. Tattooing:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Stellate wounds are indicative of contact gunshot wounds due to the close proximity of the firearm's muzzle at the time of discharge.

questions.text: The ossification center of the clavicle used to confirm bone age for legal consent to marriage is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sternal end

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The sternal end of the clavicle is significant in determining bone age, as it is the last epiphysis in the body to fuse with the shaft. This secondary ossification center appears around the age of 19-20 years and unites with the shaft by the age of 25 years. The radiological appearance of this epiphysis is particularly useful in females to confirm their bone age for legal purposes, such as consent to marriage.
  • • Ossification Centres of Clavicle
  • • Ossification Centres of Clavicle
  • • Primary Centre of Ossification
  • • Secondary Centre of Ossification
  • • The body of the clavicle ossifies from two primary centres.
  • • One medial and one lateral
  • • Primary Ossification centre for the body appears during the fifth or sixth week of fetal life
  • • The ends of clavicle ossify with two secondary centres of ossification one on each end:
  • • * Secondary centre for the medial or sternal end, appears about the eighteenth or twentieth year, and unites with the rest of the bone about the twenty-fifth year. This is the last of all the epiphyses in the body to fuse with the shaft.
  • • * Secondary centre for the lateral end of clavicle (acromial end) was described later and may occasionally be absent. This centre appears and fuses almost immediately in the 20th year. *
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Acromial end: The secondary ossification center at the acromial end appears and fuses almost immediately around the 20th year but is not typically used for determining bone age for legal purposes.
  • • Option
  • • B. Acromial end:
  • • Option C. Shaft: The primary ossification centers of the shaft appear during fetal life, but they are not relevant for assessing bone age in the context of legal consent to marriage.
  • • Option
  • • C. Shaft:
  • • Option D. Tubercle: There is no significant role of the tubercle in determining bone age for legal purposes.
  • • Option
  • • D. Tubercle:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sternal end of the clavicle is used to confirm bone age for legal consent to marriage, as it is the last epiphysis in the body to fuse with the shaft.

questions.explanation: Ans. B. False virgin

questions.text: The last organ to be affected by rigor mortis among the following is: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Nysten's law describes the progression of rigor mortis in both voluntary and involuntary muscles In this progression: Involuntary muscles (myocardium) are affected first Then follows a cephalocaudal progression in voluntary muscles: Upper eyelids Neck and jaw muscles Face Chest Upper limbs Abdomen Lower limbs Fingers and toes being the last The progression follows Nysten's law both in: Development (ascending order) Disappearance (same order) Time frame follows the "rule of 12": Takes 12 hours to develop fully Persists for 12 hours Disappears over 12 hours
  • • Nysten's law describes the progression of rigor mortis in both voluntary and involuntary muscles
  • • In this progression: Involuntary muscles (myocardium) are affected first Then follows a cephalocaudal progression in voluntary muscles: Upper eyelids Neck and jaw muscles Face Chest Upper limbs Abdomen Lower limbs Fingers and toes being the last
  • • Involuntary muscles (myocardium) are affected first Then follows a cephalocaudal progression in voluntary muscles: Upper eyelids Neck and jaw muscles Face Chest Upper limbs Abdomen Lower limbs Fingers and toes being the last
  • • Involuntary muscles (myocardium) are affected first
  • • Then follows a cephalocaudal progression in voluntary muscles: Upper eyelids Neck and jaw muscles Face Chest Upper limbs Abdomen Lower limbs Fingers and toes being the last
  • • Upper eyelids Neck and jaw muscles Face Chest Upper limbs Abdomen Lower limbs Fingers and toes being the last
  • • Upper eyelids
  • • Neck and jaw muscles
  • • Face
  • • Chest
  • • Upper limbs
  • • Abdomen
  • • Lower limbs
  • • Fingers and toes being the last
  • • The progression follows Nysten's law both in: Development (ascending order) Disappearance (same order)
  • • Development (ascending order) Disappearance (same order)
  • • Development (ascending order)
  • • Disappearance (same order)
  • • Time frame follows the "rule of 12": Takes 12 hours to develop fully Persists for 12 hours Disappears over 12 hours
  • • Takes 12 hours to develop fully Persists for 12 hours Disappears over 12 hours
  • • Takes 12 hours to develop fully
  • • Persists for 12 hours
  • • Disappears over 12 hours

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand the sequential progression of rigor mortis following Nysten's law, emphasizing the pattern of involvement from heart to the most distal parts of the body, which is crucial for establishing time since death in forensic investigations.

questions.text: Gastric lavage can be performed in case of poisoning by: ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Carbolic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Contraindications to gastric lavage:
  • ➤ Contraindications to gastric lavage:
  • ➤ Corrosive poisons such as concentrated inorganic acids (e.g. sulfuric acid, nitric acid etc.) corrode and soften the stomach wall, making it prone for perforation ( exception carbolic acid which hardens the stomach wall and gastric lavage is done safely). Risk of aspiration: Convulsive poisons, Comatose patients , Volatile poisons (hydrocarbons like kerosene) U pper gastrointestinal tract diseases: Example oesophageal varices Hypothermia Hemorrhagic diathesis
  • ➤ Corrosive poisons such as concentrated inorganic acids (e.g. sulfuric acid, nitric acid etc.) corrode and soften the stomach wall, making it prone for perforation ( exception carbolic acid which hardens the stomach wall and gastric lavage is done safely).
  • ➤ Corrosive poisons
  • ➤ exception carbolic acid
  • ➤ Risk of aspiration: Convulsive poisons, Comatose patients , Volatile poisons (hydrocarbons like kerosene)
  • ➤ Risk of aspiration: Convulsive poisons, Comatose patients
  • ➤ Volatile poisons (hydrocarbons like kerosene)

questions.text: A 25-year-old young male who was a tattoo artist was brought dead to the casualty under mysterious circumstances. His girlfriend reported he had a large tattoo on his right hand, but this was not found on examination. Which structure should be examined to get more idea of the same? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lymph nodes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Examining the regional lymph nodes can reveal traces of tattoo ink even if the tattoo itself is no longer visible on the skin, providing useful forensic evidence.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male addicted to recreational drugs, smoking and alcohol came to the OPD with complaints of excessive beating of heart and palpitations. On examination, there was episodic tachycardia and occasional extrasystole. Ophthalmic examination showed visual field defects. Which of the drugs is the likely cause?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Cocaine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug that causes significant stimulant effects on the CNS and CVS, leading to symptoms such as tachycardia, palpitations, arrhythmias, and, occasionally, visual field defects due to vasoconstriction and ischemia.

questions.text: Restriction endonuclease will act on which of the following? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:

  • ➤ 5' --AAGCTT-- 3'
  • ➤ 3' --TTCGAA-- 5'

questions.text: Match the postmortem findings and their time of appearance:(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

Explanation:

  • • Adipocere formation Time of appearance: 8-10 days Explanation: Adipocere, also known as grave wax, is a postmortem change that occurs when body fat undergoes a transformation into a waxy substance in a moist environment. This process typically begins around 8-10 days after death.
  • • Adipocere formation
  • • Time of appearance: 8-10 days Explanation: Adipocere, also known as grave wax, is a postmortem change that occurs when body fat undergoes a transformation into a waxy substance in a moist environment. This process typically begins around 8-10 days after death.
  • • Time of appearance: 8-10 days
  • • Time of appearance:
  • • Explanation: Adipocere, also known as grave wax, is a postmortem change that occurs when body fat undergoes a transformation into a waxy substance in a moist environment. This process typically begins around 8-10 days after death.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Relaxation of urethral sphincter Time of appearance: 24 hrs Explanation: After death, muscle relaxation, including the relaxation of the urethral sphincter, occurs due to the cessation of neural activity and muscle tone, typically around 24 hours postmortem.
  • • Relaxation of urethral sphincter
  • • Time of appearance: 24 hrs Explanation: After death, muscle relaxation, including the relaxation of the urethral sphincter, occurs due to the cessation of neural activity and muscle tone, typically around 24 hours postmortem.
  • • Time of appearance: 24 hrs
  • • Time of appearance:
  • • Explanation: After death, muscle relaxation, including the relaxation of the urethral sphincter, occurs due to the cessation of neural activity and muscle tone, typically around 24 hours postmortem.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Marbling of veins Time of appearance: 2-3 days Explanation: Marbling refers to the appearance of greenish-black discoloration along the veins due to the breakdown of hemoglobin and the production of hydrogen sulphide gas by bacteria. This occurs approximately 2-3 days after death.
  • • Marbling of veins
  • • Time of appearance: 2-3 days Explanation: Marbling refers to the appearance of greenish-black discoloration along the veins due to the breakdown of hemoglobin and the production of hydrogen sulphide gas by bacteria. This occurs approximately 2-3 days after death.
  • • Time of appearance: 2-3 days
  • • Time of appearance:
  • • Explanation: Marbling refers to the appearance of greenish-black discoloration along the veins due to the breakdown of hemoglobin and the production of hydrogen sulphide gas by bacteria. This occurs approximately 2-3 days after death.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Liquefaction of tissues Time of appearance: 4-5 days Explanation: Tissue liquefaction is a stage of decomposition where tissues start to break down into a liquid form. This process typically begins around 4-5 days postmortem.
  • • Liquefaction of tissues
  • • Time of appearance: 4-5 days Explanation: Tissue liquefaction is a stage of decomposition where tissues start to break down into a liquid form. This process typically begins around 4-5 days postmortem.
  • • Time of appearance: 4-5 days
  • • Time of appearance:
  • • Explanation: Tissue liquefaction is a stage of decomposition where tissues start to break down into a liquid form. This process typically begins around 4-5 days postmortem.
  • • Explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amongst postmortem findings:
  • ➤ Adipocere formation is by 8-10 days Relaxation of urethral sphincter is by 24 hrs. Marbling of veins is by 2-3 days Liquefaction of tissues is by 4-5 days
  • ➤ Adipocere formation is by 8-10 days
  • ➤ Relaxation of urethral sphincter is by 24 hrs.
  • ➤ Marbling of veins is by 2-3 days
  • ➤ Liquefaction of tissues is by 4-5 days

questions.text: A female worker from a pyrotechnic factory presents with bone pain, multiple fractures, anemia, and renal dysfunction. On examination, her jaw shows brownish discoloration of teeth without necrosis. What is the most likely causative agent? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Cadmium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The presentation suggests chronic cadmium toxicity ("Itai-itai disease"), characterized by:
  • • Osteomalacia and osteoporosis leading to multiple fractures Renal tubular dysfunction Anemia Dental manifestations including brown discoloration Common in industrial exposure (batteries, pigments, pyrotechnics)
  • • Osteomalacia and osteoporosis leading to multiple fractures
  • • Renal tubular dysfunction
  • • Anemia
  • • Dental manifestations including brown discoloration
  • • Common in industrial exposure (batteries, pigments, pyrotechnics)
  • • Other Incorrect Options:
  • • Other Incorrect Options:
  • • Option A. Phosphorus
  • • Option A. Phosphorus
  • • Causes osteonecrosis of jaw ("phossy jaw") Presents with jaw pain, loose teeth, fistulae Associated with match factory workers Does not cause systemic bone disease
  • • Causes osteonecrosis of jaw ("phossy jaw")
  • • Presents with jaw pain, loose teeth, fistulae
  • • Associated with match factory workers
  • • Does not cause systemic bone disease
  • • Option B. Antimony
  • • Option B. Antimony
  • • Primarily causes respiratory and gastrointestinal symptoms No significant bone or renal involvement Used in flame retardants and electronics Dental changes not characteristic
  • • Primarily causes respiratory and gastrointestinal symptoms
  • • No significant bone or renal involvement
  • • Used in flame retardants and electronics
  • • Dental changes not characteristic
  • • Option D. Fluorine
  • • Option D. Fluorine
  • • Causes dental and skeletal fluorosis Presents with mottled teeth (white patches) No significant renal involvement Does not cause anemia
  • • Causes dental and skeletal fluorosis
  • • Presents with mottled teeth (white patches)
  • • No significant renal involvement
  • • Does not cause anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand:
  • ➤ Different industrial toxins can affect bone metabolism Importance of distinguishing systemic vs. localized bone pathology Characteristic features of various heavy metal toxicities Role of workplace exposure in diagnosis
  • ➤ Different industrial toxins can affect bone metabolism
  • ➤ Importance of distinguishing systemic vs. localized bone pathology
  • ➤ Characteristic features of various heavy metal toxicities
  • ➤ Role of workplace exposure in diagnosis

questions.text: Identify the plant (FMGE JULY 2023)

  • • Cerebra Thevetia (Yellow Oleander): This plant is identified by its yellow, bell-shaped flowers. It is also known as a cardiotoxic plant. The yellow oleander typically has these distinct flowers and should be recognized for its toxic properties.
  • • Cerebra Thevetia (Yellow Oleander):
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Nerium Odorum (White Oleander): White in color and not bell-shaped flower. It is also cardiotoxic.
  • • Option A. Nerium Odorum (White Oleander):
  • • Option C. Aconite: Also known as monk's hood, Aconite has hood-like flowers. It is characterized by a hood-like upper part and two-lipped lower part.
  • • Option C. Aconite:
  • • Option D. Cerbera odollam: Also known as the "suicide tree", it produces white flowers, mango like fruit and this is also cardiotoxic.
  • • Option D.
  • • Cerbera odollam:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cerebra Thevetia (yellow oleander) - Yellow, bell-shaped flowers, a cardiotoxic plant.
  • ➤ Nerium Odorum (White Oleander) - White and flowers are not bell-shaped, also cardiotoxic
  • ➤ Note – Other Important flowers
  • ➤ Note – Other Important flowers
  • ➤ Trumpet shape flower – Datura
  • ➤ Digitalis Purpura flowers – arranged in elongated clusters, flower is tubular & pendant. Inside of the flower is heavily spotted

questions.text: Regarding Puppe's rule, all of the following statements are true EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: The rule is associated with bullet injuries to the cranium.

options.label: B
options.text: It is utilized to ascertain the sequence of bullet shots.

options.label: C
options.text: This rule involves the observation of fracture lines.

options.label: D
options.text: It is valuable in cases where multiple bullet injuries occur simultaneously.

questions.correct_answer: D. It is valuable in cases where multiple bullet injuries occur simultaneously.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It is valuable in cases where multiple bullet injuries occur simultaneously.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Puppe's rule is specifically applied to determine the sequence of multiple gunshot wounds to the skull when they do not occur simultaneously. The rule states that an extending fracture line will stop at a pre-existing fracture line or suture, indicating the sequence in which the impacts occurred. Thus, it cannot accurately determine the sequence when gunshot injuries happen virtually simultaneously, as the fractures may overlap or intersect ambiguously.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. The rule is associated with bullet injuries to the cranium: because Puppe's rule does indeed pertain to bullet injuries of the cranium, specifically to establish the order of multiple impacts based on fracture lines.
  • • Option A. The rule is associated with bullet injuries to the cranium:
  • • Option B. It is utilized to ascertain the sequence of bullet shots: as this statement is true; Puppe's rule helps in determining the chronological order of gunshot wounds by examining the interaction of fracture lines.
  • • Option B. It is utilized to ascertain the sequence of bullet shots:
  • • Option C. This rule involves the observation of fracture lines: because observing fracture lines is a fundamental aspect of applying Puppe's rule to ascertain the order of injuries.
  • • Option C. This rule involves the observation of fracture lines:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Puppe's rule cannot be used to determine the sequence of bullet injuries when they occur simultaneously due to overlapping and intersecting fracture lines.

questions.text: For Medical Termination of Pregnancy after 24 weeks of gestation due to fetal chromosomal abnormalities, whose presence is mandatory in the medical board? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • When conducting a medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) after 24 weeks of gestation due to fetal chromosomal abnormalities, the presence of a Radiologist in the medical board is mandatory. The Radiologist plays a crucial role in:
  • • Interpreting Advanced Imaging: They provide expertise in analyzing detailed ultrasound or other imaging results essential for diagnosing chromosomal abnormalities. Assessing Fetal Anatomy: Radiologists evaluate the structural anomalies that may be associated with chromosomal disorders. Guiding Procedural Decisions: Their input is vital in determining the most appropriate and safe methods for termination based on imaging findings. Collaborating with Other Specialists: They work alongside obstetricians and geneticists to ensure comprehensive evaluation and decision-making.
  • • Interpreting Advanced Imaging: They provide expertise in analyzing detailed ultrasound or other imaging results essential for diagnosing chromosomal abnormalities.
  • • Interpreting Advanced Imaging:
  • • Assessing Fetal Anatomy: Radiologists evaluate the structural anomalies that may be associated with chromosomal disorders.
  • • Assessing Fetal Anatomy:
  • • Guiding Procedural Decisions: Their input is vital in determining the most appropriate and safe methods for termination based on imaging findings.
  • • Guiding Procedural Decisions:
  • • Collaborating with Other Specialists: They work alongside obstetricians and geneticists to ensure comprehensive evaluation and decision-making.
  • • Collaborating with Other Specialists:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • B. Medical Geneticist: While a Medical Geneticist provides valuable insights into genetic testing and counseling, their presence is not mandated in the medical board for MTP after 24 weeks. Their expertise may be consulted as needed but is not a core requirement. C. General Surgeon: A General Surgeon does not play a direct role in the assessment or decision-making process for MTP due to chromosomal abnormalities. Their surgical skills are not pertinent to the termination procedures in this context. D. Psychiatrist: A Psychiatrist is not required on the medical board for MTP related to chromosomal abnormalities. They may be involved if there are mental health considerations, but their presence is not a standard requirement.
  • • B. Medical Geneticist: While a Medical Geneticist provides valuable insights into genetic testing and counseling, their presence is not mandated in the medical board for MTP after 24 weeks. Their expertise may be consulted as needed but is not a core requirement.
  • • B. Medical Geneticist:
  • • While a Medical Geneticist provides valuable insights into genetic testing and counseling, their presence is not mandated in the medical board for MTP after 24 weeks. Their expertise may be consulted as needed but is not a core requirement.
  • • While a Medical Geneticist provides valuable insights into genetic testing and counseling, their presence is not mandated in the medical board for MTP after 24 weeks.
  • • Their expertise may be consulted as needed but is not a core requirement.
  • • C. General Surgeon: A General Surgeon does not play a direct role in the assessment or decision-making process for MTP due to chromosomal abnormalities. Their surgical skills are not pertinent to the termination procedures in this context.
  • • C. General Surgeon:
  • • A General Surgeon does not play a direct role in the assessment or decision-making process for MTP due to chromosomal abnormalities. Their surgical skills are not pertinent to the termination procedures in this context.
  • • A General Surgeon does not play a direct role in the assessment or decision-making process for MTP due to chromosomal abnormalities.
  • • Their surgical skills are not pertinent to the termination procedures in this context.
  • • D. Psychiatrist: A Psychiatrist is not required on the medical board for MTP related to chromosomal abnormalities. They may be involved if there are mental health considerations, but their presence is not a standard requirement.
  • • D. Psychiatrist:
  • • A Psychiatrist is not required on the medical board for MTP related to chromosomal abnormalities. They may be involved if there are mental health considerations, but their presence is not a standard requirement.
  • • A Psychiatrist is not required on the medical board for MTP related to chromosomal abnormalities.
  • • They may be involved if there are mental health considerations, but their presence is not a standard requirement.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Radiologist must be included in the medical board for MTP procedures beyond 24 weeks when fetal chromosomal abnormalities are the indication, ensuring accurate interpretation of imaging and safe termination practices.

questions.text: In a case of intrauterine fetal demise, which radiological sign shows anechoic areas in the fetal brain parenchyma on ultrasound? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Bohr sign shows postmortem changes in fetal brain including:
  • • Anechoic areas in brain parenchyma Occurs due to liquefaction Appears approximately 24-48 hours after fetal death Reliable ultrasound marker of intrauterine demise
  • • Anechoic areas in brain parenchyma
  • • Occurs due to liquefaction
  • • Appears approximately 24-48 hours after fetal death
  • • Reliable ultrasound marker of intrauterine demise
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Robert's sign
  • • Option A. Robert's sign
  • • Shows gas shadows in fetal heart/great vessels Seen on radiographs, not ultrasound Appears 1-2 days after death Due to blood decomposition
  • • Shows gas shadows in fetal heart/great vessels
  • • Seen on radiographs, not ultrasound
  • • Appears 1-2 days after death
  • • Due to blood decomposition
  • • Option B. Spalding sign
  • • Option B. Spalding sign
  • • Shows overlapping of skull bones Due to brain tissue collapse Radiological finding May be absent in early deaths
  • • Shows overlapping of skull bones
  • • Due to brain tissue collapse
  • • Radiological finding
  • • May be absent in early deaths
  • • Option D. Brain sparing sign
  • • Option D. Brain sparing sign
  • • Sign of fetal compromise in living fetuses Shows preserved cerebral blood flow Not a sign of fetal death Seen on Doppler ultrasound
  • • Sign of fetal compromise in living fetuses
  • • Shows preserved cerebral blood flow
  • • Not a sign of fetal death
  • • Seen on Doppler ultrasound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand:
  • ➤ Different imaging modalities for confirming fetal death Timeline of various postmortem changes Importance of multiple signs in confirming diagnosis Specificity of different radiological and sonographic signs
  • ➤ Different imaging modalities for confirming fetal death
  • ➤ Timeline of various postmortem changes
  • ➤ Importance of multiple signs in confirming diagnosis
  • ➤ Specificity of different radiological and sonographic signs

questions.text: Sequence of Rigor Mortis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Head to foot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rigor mortis follows a sequence known as Nysten's Rule, developing and passing from head to foot, starting with the upper body and ending with the lower extremities.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a legal rule concerning the criminal responsibility of the insane? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Haase's Rule

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Haase's Rule is unrelated to criminal responsibility; it is a method for determining the fetal age based on crown-heel length measurements, indicating the development stages of a fetus. This rule is purely medical and has no bearing on legal assessments of insanity or criminal responsibility.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. McNaughten’s Rule: as an incorrect choice because McNaughten’s Rule directly pertains to determining criminal responsibility based on the defendant's understanding of right and wrong during the act.
  • • Option A. McNaughten’s Rule:
  • • Option B. Durham’s Rule: as an incorrect choice because Durham’s Rule assesses criminal responsibility by examining whether the act was a product of mental disease or defect.
  • • Option B. Durham’s Rule:
  • • Option C. Atkin’s Rule: as an incorrect choice because Atkin’s Rule, similar to an irresistible impulse rule, evaluates criminal responsibility based on the defendant's capacity to control his actions due to mental disease.
  • • Option C. Atkin’s Rule:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Haase's Rule is a medical guideline for estimating fetal age and does not deal with the criminal responsibility of the insane.

questions.text: Identify the following post-mortem change. ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Suggillation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post Mortem Staining (PMS)
  • ➤ Post Mortem Staining (PMS)
  • ➤ It is the settling of the blood in the dependent, portion of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish red discoloration of the skin. Other names of PMS are: Hypostasis livor mortis Vibices Suggillation Postmortem Lividity Cadaveric lividity Darkening of death It is present on dependent areas, but absent on pressure areas as the blood vessels get compressed. In a supine body the pressure areas are back of chest, buttocks etc as these are in the direct contact with ground.
  • ➤ It is the settling of the blood in the dependent, portion of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish red discoloration of the skin.
  • ➤ Other names of PMS are: Hypostasis livor mortis Vibices Suggillation Postmortem Lividity Cadaveric lividity Darkening of death
  • ➤ Hypostasis livor mortis Vibices Suggillation Postmortem Lividity Cadaveric lividity Darkening of death
  • ➤ Hypostasis
  • ➤ livor mortis
  • ➤ Vibices
  • ➤ Suggillation
  • ➤ Postmortem Lividity
  • ➤ Cadaveric lividity
  • ➤ Darkening of death
  • ➤ It is present on dependent areas, but absent on pressure areas as the blood vessels get compressed. In a supine body the pressure areas are back of chest, buttocks etc as these are in the direct contact with ground.

questions.text: Which of the following has protective as well as lubricating property? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mucins have both protective and lubricating properties, forming a barrier on epithelial surfaces and reducing friction in various body tracts. They are essential for maintaining the integrity and function of mucosal surfaces.

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Hypothermia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Paradoxical undressing occurs in hypothermia victims who, despite experiencing extremely low temperatures, remove their clothing due to a sudden and misleading sensation of warmth.
